div.head: To the READER.
div.p:
NO ≈øooner did this Letter fall into my ‚Ä¢ ands, but ≈øtraight I had a thought to publi≈øh it; to the end that all the world might be acquainted with the deportment of that Faction in England, which for the≈øe three or foure yeares together hath cau≈øed the effu≈øion of ≈øo much blo ‚Ä¢ d there. Some happily of our religion in France will at fir≈øt glance di≈øreli≈øh my de≈øigne: but after they have throughly weighed it, I am confident they will all joyntly acknowledge their engagements to me for pre≈øenting them with a worke which undeceives their credulity, who ≈øtrongly fancy that we countenance their irregular proceedings, and meet in the ≈øame thoughts with tho≈øe that have beene the unhappy contrivers of them. And it may be al≈øo that ≈øome among the Catholiques will be ready to ≈øay this is but the opinion meerely of ≈øome one particular Per≈øon, and that all Prote≈øtants will not ≈øub≈øcribe unto it. But I prote≈øt before God, that I never heard of any knowing judicious man with us, who≈øe di≈øcour≈øe agrees not with that of the Author here; and it were to be wi≈øhed that the whole world would conforme it ≈øelfe to the example of the Reformed in France. Were it ≈øo, there ≈øhould no Prince ≈øtand in need of guards, or be forced to levy Armies for the defence of his Per≈øon again≈øt the in≈øolence and Rebellion of Subjects. There would be no more undermining the peace of the Church, which would now cheri≈øh a compleat union & ab≈øolute corre≈øpondency betwixt its owne and the ≈øecular government, confining it ≈øelfe to its proper limits, and having ≈øtill a ≈øpeciall regard to that ≈øubordination which is required of it. I ≈øpeake this, Reader, becau≈øe it is true; though ≈øundry conceive otherwi≈øe of it, either meerely out of a cu≈øtome they have embraced wholly to ≈øurrender them≈øelves unto the ≈øway of other mens judgement: or becau≈øe they have a ≈øtrong prejudice again≈øt the Di≈øcipline we practice, as if it were not altogether ≈øo agreeable with Monarchy. Iudge of it by the grounds thereof, and pau≈øe a while in comparing our actions with our doctrine (without re≈øting upon any other con≈øideration)
and thou can≈øt not but conclude, that the ≈øole drift of our intentions hath ever beene to defend our ≈øelves rather by the weapons of the Spirit, then tho≈øe of the fle≈øh, and that we joine in an unanimous dete≈øtation of all ≈øuch as maintaine it lawfull to make u≈øe of temporall violence for promoting the truth of the Go≈øpell. This Letter I here pre≈øent thee with, is ca≈øt in the mould of the true Prote≈øtants. It appeares in defence of their doctrine touching the power of Kings, and the obedience of Subjects; withall condemning their proceedings, who under a pretence of purging the Church from its errours and enormities, and rein≈øtating Chri≈øtians in their lo≈øt Liberty, maske a de≈øigne of engaging the whole world in a horrible confu≈øion. I cannot informe thee, who is the author of it. Thus much only thou maie≈øt know, that ≈øojourning in England, a certaine Mini≈øter, (a freind of his, and a man of great abilities) reque≈øted of him a large account in writing of the pre≈øent di≈øtempers there. He hath done it, thou ≈øee≈øt. He paints them in their proper colours, points out the contrivers of them, and their aimes. He makes it legible to the world, that this Parliament is nothing, in generality, but a ≈øeditious Crew, bending all their indeavours again≈øt the Lawes of the Realme, with a de≈øigne to turne all ‚Ä¢ op≈øieturvy; nor this Synod but (for the greate≈øt part al≈øo) an A≈ø≈øembly of Heretiques and Ignoramu≈ø≈øes, that trample upon all the maximes of Chri≈øtianity, and entertaine no thoughts, but of an Epidemicall confu≈øion. That the People (in gro≈ø≈øe) are wholly ≈øet upon Anarchy, being co≈øened by a con≈øent wrought in them by the Parliament touching the Tyranny (as they phra≈øe it) of Kings; and intoxicated by the Synod with the hopes of a mo≈øt ble≈ø≈øed condition, were they but once freed from that in≈øupportable yoake of the Clergy. If happily out of this throng God hath ≈øeque≈øtred ≈øome wellaffected per≈øons for him≈øelfe, they are ≈øo thinne a company, that they dare not declare them≈øelves, for feare of being overborne by the malice and number of the re≈øt, as divers have already beene. Weigh by this, Reader, if the malady be not great, the remedy difficult.

div.head: A LETTER CONCERNing the pre≈øent troubles in England.
div.p:
WHEN I had the Honour to give you an account in writing of my abode here in England, I had not the lea≈øt intention to acquaint you with all my thoughs touching the pre≈øent di≈øtempers of the ≈øame. Not that the feare of any cen≈øure could amate me, although I am not ignorant, that he who would give a faithfull indifferent relation thereof, mu≈øt oppo≈øe him≈øelfe to tho≈øe ordinary impre≈ø≈øions, which men have already entertained concerning them. And if this amu≈øe them (as no doubt but it will) that I cannot prevaile with my ≈øelfe to nou≈ø ‚Ä¢ e them on in an errour, whereinto the malice or ignorance of their mi≈øinformers hath ≈øo deeply plunged them, I ≈øhall for a long time runne the hazard of their disfavour, as being re≈øolved not to write any thing but of what I have beene an eye-witne≈ø≈øe, and which you will finde to beare no great harmony with the common voice. It is undoubtedly a matter of no triviall concernment to provide that the world be herein di≈øabu≈øed, and that the truth of a bu≈øine≈ø≈øe of this nature be no longer liable to mi≈øapprehen≈øion. Wherein you are ≈øomewhat intere≈ø≈øed your ≈øelfe by that common profe≈ø≈øion you make in the li≈øt of ≈øuch con≈øcientious Per≈øons as are de≈øigned to ≈øuperintend the good of People, and to ≈øteere their Con≈øciences aright. And I hope you (with many moe be≈øides) will not be wanting to give the world ≈øatisfaction what a di≈øparity you conceive betwixt the proceedings of

For my part I finde ≈øo little conformity in the≈øe latter to our fir≈øt Reformers, that I thinke it concernes them to guild over with ≈øome ≈øpecious pretext the poi≈øon they diffu≈øe, as being their Enemies, not their Followers; or if perhaps they make a ≈øhew of treading the ≈øame path, 'tis not out of any intention to joine and a≈ø≈øociate with them, but rather to marre and undoe the worke which by their meanes was ≈øet on foote in the world. And in truth, Sir, what can be hoped for from ≈øuch a Rabble as this (naturally ≈øo in≈øolent and head≈øtrong) but the markes of Rebellion both again≈øt God and Man? it being their ≈øole employment to advance factions and fidings, when ever the affaires either of Religion or Policy are brought into agitation. So that if you abate hence all who have, either (out of haughtines and unbridledne≈ø≈øe of Spirit) combined again≈øt their Prince, or nouri≈øhed the Schi≈ømes and ruptures of the Church in broaching their empty and wild Fancies, I dare not promi≈øe that the re≈øidue ≈øhall afford you either a Body of Subjects, or a Congregation of Chri≈øtians.

I intend not to di≈øcour≈øe of tho≈øe of the King's Party; wherein ('tis true) there be ≈øome apparently culpable, but yet more of ≈øuch as I may call really unfortunate, tho≈øe alone I meane, that make up the greate≈øt number of Reformed and Hone≈øt men in that Kingdome. I ≈øhall confine my Di≈øcour≈øe to tho≈øe, who beare the World in hand, they are at oddes with nothing but Popery, which in their jealous apprehen≈øions was taking roote in England againe. With this pretty cheate they have got the approbation of not a few Prote≈øtants, who (without ≈øifting their de≈øigne) are by this meanes engaged to applaude a pa ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ icidiall attempt upon the Soveraigne Maje≈øty, and a villainous plot again≈øt the Sacred Over≈øeers of the Church. Either of which two crimes is doubtle≈ø≈øe one of the mo≈øt e≈ø≈øentiall notes of reprobation; nor is it po≈ø≈øible for him to make good the profe≈ø≈øion of Chri≈øtianity, who complies or holds any the lea≈øt corre≈øpondence with ≈øuch as are knowingly guilty of the ≈øame.

Your new-fangled Mini≈øters of London are mo≈øtly involved in the equall guilt of both. For who knowes not how at the very fir≈øt ri≈øe of the≈øe troubles they preached openly to the People, That Kings
are not to be obeyed if once they a≈ø≈øault their Liberties and Priviledges (which in their con≈øtruction is the fir≈øt ≈øteppe to Tyranny) or taking upon them to intermeddle in Church affaires, they fall upon any ab≈øurd & impious opinion. Wherein they came nothing ≈øhort of Cardinall Bellarmine, who writes, That if Princes ≈øhall once apply them≈øelves to the protection of Here≈øy or exerci≈øe of Tyranny, they are left to the mercy of the Pope, and the Church, who are fir≈øt to excommunicate them, then to ab≈øolve the Subjects from the Oath of Allegiance, and they upon this di≈øcharge, a≈ø≈øoone as they can be provided of a competent ≈øtrength are to employ it again≈øt them, to expo≈øe them to puni≈øhment, and by all meanes fei≈øible to dethrone them. A wonderfull thing that they who are ≈øuch profe≈ø≈øed enemies to the Je≈øuites, that u≈øe their per≈øons (when they ≈øeize them) with ≈øo much inhumanity, and for the continued revolution of ≈øo many yeares have expo≈øed their bodies quartered to all pa≈ø≈øengers (as a ≈øpectacle of horrour) upon their mo≈øt eminent Gates, ≈øhould notwith≈øtanding ≈øhake hands with them in a point for the which at fir≈øt they did ≈øo much abhorre them. Would you not conclude that they are all alike the Di≈øciples of Mariana, and the Agents of a Boniface? what affinity is there betwixt the≈øe Doctours and Saint Ambro≈øe? when this great Saint, this reall Chri≈øtian perceived that the Arians were about to po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe them≈øelves of the Church in Milan, with the approbation of the Emperour Valentinian, he addre≈ø≈øed him≈øelfe unto that Prince in the≈øe tearmes; Royall Sir, we intreate, we pre≈øume not to fight. If the Prince will needs make u≈øe of his Supreame power, I am ready to di≈øcharge the duty of a Prelate. I ≈øhall ≈øtand upon my defence, but 'tis in the petitions of the poore. I can ‚Ä¢ emoane me, I can weepe, I can ‚Ä¢ igh; but again≈øt Armes, again≈øt Souldiers, again≈øt the Gothes, my onely weapons are teares, nor ought I to u≈øe any other manner of re≈øi≈øtance what≈øoever. And in another place, If the Kingdome ≈øhall lye panting under the pre≈ø≈øures of Tyranny, I am ready to ≈øuffer any kind of violence, even Death it ≈øelfe. Be≈øides that univer≈øall injunction laid upon Chri≈øtians, to put up injuries with patience, (God having re≈øerved unto him≈øelfe the right of revenging by the power of his Ju≈øtice, as Saint Gregory upon Job ≈øpeakes, Man being uncapable of performing it, but with a heart fraught with malice) he knew I ≈øay be≈øides this what David once ≈øung to God; again≈øt thee onely have I ≈øinned: upon which pa≈ø≈øage (in the Apology he compiled for him) he thus comments;
He was a King, and ≈øo not within the reach of the Lawes: Vi ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
lis delictorum liberi ≈øunt reges; if I may borrow the atte≈øtation of ≈øo divine a pen. Now if David were not mi≈øtaken, if Saint Ambro≈øe ≈øpake rea≈øon in this point, with Saint Chry≈øo≈øtome, who a≈ø≈øures us ≈øo punctually, that Kings are above the Lawes; What ≈øhall we thinke of our up≈øtart Reformers, that have placed Kings below their People, and ≈øtirre up the People again≈øt their Kings? It is a pregnant evidence they are ≈øwayed by that ≈øpirit of rebellion, which heretofore animated the Gregories, the Bonifaces, the Mariana's, the Bellarmines, to attempt upon the Honour and life of Kings, rather then by that ≈øpirit of wi≈øedome and meekene≈ø≈øe, which moved Solomon to leave this divine precept behind him, (equally obliging all that have not forfeited their rea≈øon) never to divorce the re≈øpect due unto Kings from that which they owe unto God him≈øelfe; and in ca≈øe they ≈øhall pre≈øume to do otherwi≈øe, a≈ø≈øociating them≈øelves with ≈øuch Libertines as refu≈øe to pay the tribute of obedience, to be afraid their calamity doe not ari≈øe ≈øuddainly. The Pulpits here are full of none but Preachers of di≈øcord and divi≈øion betwixt the King and his Subjects. In lieu of prai≈øes, magnifying the name of God, Invocation of the Holy Spirit, Confe≈ø≈øion of Sinnes, ≈øighs and groanes for the commi≈ø≈øion thereof, here is nothing to be heard but reproaches, revilings and accu≈øations. Charity in all other places throwes her skirt over the Errours ≈øhe di≈øcovers, be they as great and numerous as can be. 'Tis charity here to lay them naked in the view of the world, and if there be no reall ones, to devi≈øe ≈øome, that ≈øo they may never be de≈øtitute of a forgery wherewith to traduce their Prince. His Per≈øon and Actions are both expo≈øed to publique reproaches: The Churches Ring of nothing but declamations again≈øt Him; and if happily ≈øome ≈ømall relickes of ≈øhame have ever ≈ølacked the heate of tho≈øe bawling Predicants, or railing Scriblers, impudence makes others in compen≈øation to double the Cry. the corruption of Rome, which gave life unto it, had nothing in it of more venimous con≈øequence, then this we ≈øee here, ≈øave that the Emi≈ø≈øaries and Boute-feus of the Engli≈øh Confederacy have not as yet imbrued their hands in the bloud of their King.

There were ≈øome in the infancy of the Church, who ≈øtrained Chri≈øtian liberty ≈øo farre, that they condemned it as unju≈øt for the Enfranchi≈øed of God, and ≈øuch as were guided by his ≈øpirit, to be ≈øubject to the command of any creature.

The Donati≈øts ≈øucked the ≈øame poi≈øon from them, which afterwards diffu≈øed it ≈øelfe among the Anabapti≈øts; and in fine reached us al≈øo, by meanes of ≈øome who gave a ≈øecond birth to this Here≈øy, which now walkes up and downe here in great bravery, under pretences very ≈øpecious in the apprehen≈øion of ≈øome ≈øhallow Judgements. And though I conceive this will not be to the generall prejudice of the Reformed Churches in Europe (by rea≈øon of that ju≈øt jealou≈øy which Princes ought to entertaine, that they hold no intelligence among≈øt them≈øelves, and that they doe not all bandy togethr again≈øt the rights and prerogatives of their re≈øpective dominions.) Yet it mu≈øt needs „Äà‚óä„Äâ to their ≈øhame atlea≈øt, if they doe not openly declare again≈øt the villany of their proceedings, and the iniquity of their de≈øignes; e≈øpecially ≈øince they have had the impudence to invite them to an imitation of their example, and to ≈øteppe in for the ≈øupport of their faction.
